explanation: Answers for repository initialization, cloning depth, remotes, and hygiene best practices.

answerKey.rationale: git init sets up a .git directory in the current path.
Shallow clones reduce data transfer for pipelines or temporary checkouts.
Bare repositories omit a working tree and host only the Git database.
remote add and set-url --add associate extra remotes or push URLs.
Ignore patterns, global templates, and cleaning guard against accidental artifacts.
Documented directory layouts and docs/ improve onboarding.
Submodules pin commits; teammates must init/update them and URLs can be relative.
git init --template copies hooks and config from a template dir.
Ignoring .env files protects secrets from version control.

keyPoints: git init and clone are the launching points for repository work.
Shallow clones accelerate CI by limiting history depth.
Bare repositories act as servers without working trees.
Remote commands manage fetch/push URLs for collaboration meshes.
Ignore files and cleaning workflows prevent noisy commits.
Structured directories and documentation improve onboarding.
Hooks can be centralized with templates and core.hooksPath.
Submodules require initialization and lock to commit IDs.
Templates seed consistent tooling across repos.
Secret management relies on ignoring credential files.
